article:
A 'biocide' is a chemical substance or microorganism which can deter, render
harmless, or exert a controlling effect on any harmful organism by chemical or
biological means. Biocides are commonly used in medicine, agriculture, forestry,
and industry. Biocidal substances and products are also employed as anti-fouling
agents or disinfectants under other circumstances: chlorine, for example, is
used as a short-life biocide in industrial water treatment but as a disinfectant
in swimming pools. Many biocides are synthetic, but a class of 'natural
biocides', derived from, e.g., bacteria and plants, includes brassica
oleracea, brassica oleracea gemmifera, and clostridium botulinum bacteria.

A biocide can be:
* A pesticide: this includes fungicides, herbicides, insecticides, algicides,
  molluscicides, miticides and rodenticides.
* An antimicrobial: this includes germicides, antibiotics, antibacterials,
  antivirals, antifungals, antiprotozoals and antiparasites. See also
  spermicide.

Biocide can also refer to the destruction of life, a form of omnicide that
affects every living thing, not just humans; one who wishes that everything in
the entire world, or universe, face extinction, is labeled a 'Biocidist', or
having 'biocidal' ideologies.
